msContents.summary: Two folios of an illuminated black-paper manuscript of the Saptavāra (containing only the end of the Vajravidāraṇā and the beginnig of the Gaṇapatihṛdayā). The Saptavāra ‘Seven Days’ usually incorporates the Vasudhārā, Vajravidāraṇā, Gaṇapatihṛdayā, Uṣṇīṣavijayā, Parṇaśavarī/Prajñāpāramitā, Mārīcī, and Grahamātṛkā. This collection associates each dhāraṇī with a specific day of the week, a tradition going back to at least the sixteenth century in Nepal.

msItem.title: Saptavāra
msItem.incipit: [6r1, Vajravidāraṇā] karaṃ,, sarvvavidyācchedanakaraṃ,, sarvvavidyāstaṃbhanakaraṃ,, sarvvakarmmavidhvaṃsanakaraṃ¦[6r2] parakarmmavidrāpaṇakaraṃ,, sarvvagrahotsādanaṃkaraṃ,, sarvvagrahavimokṣaṇakaraṃ,, sarva¦[6r3] bhūtāpakarṣaṇakaraṃ,, sarvvavidyāmantrakarmmaparāyaṇaṃ |,,,
msItem.explicit: [6v3, Vajravidāraṇā] sarvvaśrutrūn_ ghaṭa 2 saṃ[6v4]ghāṭaya 2 sarvavidyā vajra 2 sphoṭaya vuja 2 kaṭa vajra 2 maṭa vajra 2 vajra sanīlavajrasuvajrāya [6v5] svāhā | oṃ he he phūllani nisatraghuna phullaniphulakuru 2 vajāya svāhā || oṃ vajaki
msItem.rubric: [22r1, Grahamātṛkā] $ oṃ namo,,, ratnatrayāya || na[miniature]mo sarvabuddhabodhisatvebhya [22r2] || namo bhagavatya āryyagaha¦[miniature]mātṛkāyai ||
msItem.incipit: [22r2, Grahamātṛkā] eva mayā sa[22r3]śrum ekasmi samaye bhagavān_ [miniature] aḍavovatyāṃ mahānaga[22r4]ryā viharati sma ||
msItem.explicit: [22v3, Grahamātṛkā] tadyathā || vajrapāṇinā ca nāma bodhisattvena mahāsa[22v4]tvena,, vajracandrena ca nāma bodhisattvena,, mahāsattvena vajravegena ca nā bodhisattvena ma[22v5]hāsattvena,, vajrasanena ca nāma bodhisatvena,, mahāsatvena,, vajravināyakena ca nāma bodhi

supportDesc.foliation: Nepālākṣara numerals, mid-left margin, verso (numerals 6 and 22).
Nepālākṣarā numerals, mid-right margin, verso (numerals 2 and 1; this foliation restarts for each dhāraṇī).

layout.p: 5 lines per page, approximately 33 akṣaras per line.

Double marginal frame lines in silver ink. Traces of ruling. The first and last lines as well as the outermost akṣaras on both left and right margins are in silver ink, thus forming a frame for the inner area written in golden ink. The numbers in the texts indicating repetitions of parts of mantras are also in silver ink.

handNote.desc: Nepālākṣarā in golden and silver ink.

decoNote.desc:
The beginnings of the various dhāraṇis are decorated with polychrome miniatures of approximately 5.5 cm in width, put in the centre of the page and protected by Japanese paper. The only one preserved in this fragmentary manuscript is the following:
On f. 22v, representation the goddess Grahamātṛkā.

item.marginalia:
The versos of the two folios bear writings on the left margin with the names of the week days related to the respective texts:
[6v] somavā 2
[22v] śanicavā

history.provenance:
Bought by Wright, Daniel Dr. D. Wright
in 1873-6.
